May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised, that
when I came to
e Hage
e 27 of
e last, I found
e
most of
e
states
away, being all invited by
e
Co.
of Hohenlo
, to be at his mariage w
t
e
Countesse of
Bueren
, w
ch
was sol
e
nised at
Bueren
a litle towne
w
t
a Castel appertening to
e Countesse, between
Cu-
lenbourgh
and
Tiel.
I doe finde in like
maner,
at
e
Provinces
have not yelded as yet to
e
Councels
proposition, for
e extraordinarie contribu-
tion of this yere: for w
ch
they have demaunded eight
score thousand poundes sterling: w
ch
is seventie thou-
sand more, then was ever yet required,
e last yere
excepted. Howe it will be obtained it is very
uncertaine: but yet all men are in hope,
at it will
be raised in
e end: albeit I am told,
at my c
o
ming
heere so soone will rather hurt then helpe it forward.
For I doe serve my self of divers reasons, to drawe
them on to pay their debtes, of w
ch
some will take
hold to excuse their contributing:
at if their grant
had bin past before I had come hither, it had bin un-
doubtedly a farre fitter opportunitie. Yester-
day morning I had my audience of
e states, of whome
I was heard in a full assemblie: but I had no other
answear, then they are wont to deliver in all suche
affaires, That they will take some time to thinke up
o
it, requiring to have my proposition in writing, wher-
of heere inclosed I send
e copie to yo
r
L. I will
hasten their answear as muche as I may, and so-
licit them
e while to give her
Ma
tie
content, First
by some good portion of mony in hand: secondly by
some annual paim
t
, till all be discharged: and
lastly by abating a part of her present expenses.
They are very muche troubled w
t
this mater, and waxe
so silent up
o
it, as I can not yet imagine what
successe I shall have: but I am in good hope, to learne
out somw
at
of their purpose, and to write it in my next.
fol.29v
This day I am to deale w
t
e Councel of Estate, to whome
I will deliver her Ma
ties
l
re
, and particpat as muche,
as I proposed to
e states. But
Co. Maurice
is in
Gel-
erland
, but w
t
whome I must deale altogether by l
re
s,
if I see any likelihood
at he will stay in those quarters.
Coronel Stuart
is come hither from
e
Scottishe King
, and
hath delivered his message: wherof all
at I can learne,
is
at he seeketh to renue
e ancient amities and alli
a
ces
between
e two contreis: and w
t
all is a suitor to be as-
sisted by them against his rebels at home. Whether
e
K
s
desire be for mony or men, I shall not be able to signifie
directly, till I have spoken w
t
e Coronel
himself, or w
t
some
of
e states, w
ch
I purpose w
t
e soonest, and will adver-
tise accordingly. The report
at hath gone
of
e Germane Ambassado
rs
,
at should come to treat
of Peace, is still a foote in these c
o
treis. It is determi-
ned, they say,
at of 12 speciall persons deputed ther-
unto, there shall 6 repaire to
Brussels,
and 6 to
this place, to witte, two from
e Ecclesiastical state,
two from
e Princes and other two from
e townes:
and
at certaine Heraldes wearing their coates shall
be sent before, to declare to
e people in places where
they passe,
e occasion of their comming. But I can
not yet perceave,
at they have yet resolved heere, w
at
course they will take for admitting or stopping their
comming: though I see no inclinati
o
,
at they will
enter into treatie. Heere hath gone a speeche
of late, of 3 townes taken by
e
D. of Bouillon
, in
e land of
Luxenbourgh,
Juois, La Frette, and Clerancy
w
ch
lie upon a branche of
e Mose: w
t
all it is said
at
he hath defeated 11 Cornets of
e Enemies horse: but
though
e newes came hither about 6 daies sins, it is
no further yet c
o
firmed. About
e same time we
were also advertised,
at
e Castle of
Huy
a strong
place in
e land of
Liege,
lieng up
o
e Mose, neere
to
e Citie of Liege, is surprised by certaine souldiers
fol.30r
of
e states, w
ch
were p
nt
ly seconded by divers other
troupes: but howe they will speede it is doubted
very muche, because
e contrey there is populous, and
full of gentlemen, w
ch
are very well provided of
warlicke furniture. But if they chaunce to hold
e
place, considering
at
e D. of Bouillon is there at
hand w
t
his armie, w
ch
are saied, together with the
states forces, to make 9000 foote, and 1500 horse, it
will prove a very speciall annoiance to
e Enemies
actions. It is held for certaine heere,
at
e
mutined Italians have accorded w
t
Ernestus
: for w
ch
many men blame
e states of these contreis,
at they
cutte them not in peeces, when it was in their power.
It is written from
Andwerpe,
at
Richardot,
Asson-
ville and Vasseur, principal persons of
e Spanishe
Councel at Brussels, are displaced by
e
King,
but
there are
at doubt
e certaintie. They are
greatly grieved heere,
at they can not stand assu-
red of these Englishe troupes w
ch
they intertaine, being
hindred by it muche in making their designes, for
not knowing w
at
forces they may imploy in any enterprise
At my being in
Middelbourgh
I receaved
a letter from
S
r
Robert Cecill
, w
t
a second discourse of
the Scottish affaires, wherof, in as muche as no other
mater is yet offered unto me, to write to his Hono
r
I humbly beseeche yow to give him some intelligence.
And so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage

5 1594.

r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodly
Heere is a bruit at this very instant,
at
both
e Castle and towne of Huy are in o
r
possession: but w
t
all it is said,
at of
e nombers
of o
r
horse, w
ch
went to succo
r
those places, as neede
should require, being 7 or 8 companies, returning
homeward w
t
their pray, w
ch
they say was very great,
3 or 4 cornets in
e avantgard were cleane defeated
by an Embuscado of
e Enemie, and
e rest
put to flight. Howe true it is I can not signifie,
but it carieth great likelihood, and it is reported
very constantly.
